**The Lure of the Kitchen**

When I was at university, I decided I wanted to be a chef. My friends thought this was a strange choice. Most of us did not want to be cooks. It is not a nice job. Chefs have very hard lives. The work is long and difficult, and they do not earn much money.

But this did not stop me. I was not happy at university. The work was hard, and I did not like the people. Being a chef seemed like a good way to escape. It felt honest and real, unlike my life at college.

But I did not want to cook just because I was a student. I also thought it was beautiful. I first understood this when I ate at a famous restaurant in London. The food was amazing. I still remember my first dish. I finished the meal and felt so happy I wanted to cry. I felt light and warm for days after.

After that, I really wanted to learn the secrets of cooking. I changed my student life to get ready for a life as a chef. I stopped caring about my history studies. My real learning came from reading cookbooks, going to food markets, and cooking big meals.

**The Swimming Lesson**

My school's swimming teacher was a small, strong man with tattoos on his arms. He used to be in the army. I asked him to teach me to dive. First, he told me to sit by the pool, put my hands up, and roll into the water. I practiced that for a long time.

The next time, he taught me to stand up and dive from the side of the pool. The teacher was very strict. Every time I came up from the water, he was not happy. He shouted, "Don't look down, look up! Keep your legs straight! Point your toes!"

The next week, I went to the high diving board. It was very high and I was scared. The noisy pool became quiet. I moved my arms like I was taught, tried to look up, and jumped. For a short time, I felt like I was flying. When I hit the water, it was not a good dive. My legs were not straight. The teacher looked at me and shook his head. But I was still very, very happy. I thought, "This is what it means to be free as a bird."

**The Traveller**

For most of us, a comfortable bed, clean water, and being safe are the most important things. So, travellers seem very strange and interesting to us. These are people who love the unknown. They choose to do dangerous things. They climb high, icy mountains. They sail alone in small boats on big seas. They will eat insects if they have no other food. They live for months with danger and the promise of new things.

It is easy to say these people are just strange. We can put them in a group with other unusual people, like hermits or writers. They are real, but their world is very different from ours. We are happy to go back to our safe world with modern things like microwaves. We are glad that the only danger in our day is maybe crossing a busy street.

**Sailing**

Jonathan Raban is afraid of the sea. He says it is not his natural place. That is probably why he sails so much. He does not say he is a great sailor, but he is a good one. The main reason he sails is because he is a writer. He likes to write about his sailing trips. Sailing always gives him exciting stories to write about.

Raban's small boat has a machine. It tells him exactly where he is on the sea. He likes this machine, but he is not happy with other sailing tools. He thinks the compass was a bad invention. He says it changed how people and the sea work together. Now, the person sailing just looks at the compass. He does not need to watch the waves or feel the sea. The ocean, which was once a living place, is now just empty space. Because the sailor's job is easy, a machine can often do it instead. This may be why Raban had so much time to look carefully at the water.
text_B1:
**The Lure of the Kitchen**

When I was at university, I decided I wanted to be a chef. For my friends, this was a strange choice. Most of us wanted different, better jobs. On the surface, being a chef seems like a bad job. Chefs have very difficult lives: the hours are long, the work is hard and stressful, and the pay is low.

But these things did not stop me. I was not happy at university. The studies were difficult, and the people were not very friendly. Being a chef seemed like the perfect way to escape this. It offered a real purpose that my student life did not have.

My wish to cook was not just because I was a student. It was also about a beautiful idea. I first understood this after a meal at a famous London restaurant. It was amazing. I still remember my first course. After the meal, I felt so emotional I wanted to thank the chef. I felt happy and light for days.

After that, I really wanted to learn the secrets of this amazing skill. I changed my student life to prepare for a career in cooking. My history studies felt fake, keeping me from my real goal. I learned what I needed by reading cookbooks, visiting food markets, and cooking big meals.

**The Swimming Lesson**

The school's swimming teacher was a small, strong man who used to be in the army. He had tattoos on his arms. When I asked him to teach me to dive, he told me to sit by the pool, put my hands over my head, and roll forward, pushing with my feet. I practised this until the lesson ended. The next time, he taught me to stand up and dive from the side. The teacher was very strict. Every time I came up from the water, he looked at me with dislike and said, 'Don't look down, look up!' 'Keep your legs straight.' 'Point your toes!' The next week, I went to the high diving board. It was very high and I felt scared standing there. Slowly, the noise from the pool disappeared and everything became quiet. I moved my arms as I was taught, tried to look up, and jumped. For a short moment, I felt like I was flying. When I hit the water, my body bent and my legs went everywhere. The teacher looked at me with no respect and shook his head. But even he could not ruin my happy feeling. I thought, so this is what it means to be 'free as a bird'.

**The Traveller**

For people like me, who think a comfortable bed, running water, and a good chance of living until tomorrow are very important, the traveller is hard to understand but also interesting. These are people who love the dangerous call of the unknown. They choose to risk their lives by climbing icy, dangerous mountains. They sail alone in small boats on huge seas. They will eat insects if there is no better food. They can live for months, day and night, in the shadow and the hope of the unknown.

It is easy to say these people are just strange, and they are. We can put them in a group with other unusual people like hermits or writers. They do exist, but their strange, uncomfortable world is very different from our normal lives. We can tell ourselves it is not important. We can be happy to return to our world of microwave ovens and telephones, glad that the only risks to our health are normal ones, like running across a busy street.

**Sailing**

Jonathan Raban is afraid of the sea. He says it is not his natural place, which is probably why he spends so much time on it. He does not say he is a world-class sailor, but he is clearly a good one. His main reason for sailing is that he is a writer, and he likes to write about his sailing trips. Sailing always gives him exciting stories and successes to write about.

Raban's small boat has an electronic machine that tells sailors their exact position anywhere on Earth. He likes this machine, but he has some old-fashioned ideas about other sailing tools. He believes the invention of the compass was a bad thing. It caused a 'big break in the relationship between people and the sea'. Raban says that since people started using the compass about a thousand years ago, it has become the main thing the sailor looks at. Because of this, the sailor no longer has to watch the waves and feel the sea. The ocean, which was once a place full of life, is now just an empty space. Since the sailor's job is just to keep the boat going straight, a machine can often do it instead. This may be why Raban had so much time to look carefully at the waves.
text_B2:
The Attraction of the Kitchen

When I was at university, I decided I wanted to become a chef. This was an unusual choice among people my age. Cooking was not one of the popular jobs that most of us wanted. On the surface, it seems like an unappealing job. Chefs are known for having difficult lives: the hours are long, the work is stressful and repetitive, and the pay is low.

But these things did not discourage me. I was unhappy at university. The studies were difficult, and the social life felt closed-off and full of people who thought they were important. Becoming a chef seemed like the perfect way to escape this intellectual and social showing off. It offered a sense of purpose and honesty that was missing from my university life.

But my wish to cook wasn't just a reaction to being a student. It also came from an artistic idea. I first understood this when I had a meal at a famous London restaurant. It was an amazing experience. I still remember my first course clearly. When I finished that meal, I felt so emotional I wanted to cry at the chef's feet. For days afterwards, I felt light and happy.

After that, I really wanted to learn the secrets of this wonderful skill. I changed my student life to prepare for my future in the cooking world. My history degree felt like a fake activity that kept me from my real goal. I educated myself by reading cookbooks, exploring food markets, and making complicated meals.

Extract from a novel

The school's swimming teacher was a former army sergeant. He was short, very muscular, and had tattoos on his arms. When I asked him to teach me to dive, he told me to sit on the side of the pool, put my hands above my head, and roll forward, pushing with my feet. I practised that move until the lesson ended. The next time, he had me stand up and dive from the side. The teacher was very strict, and every time I came up from the water he looked at me with disapproval. 'Don't look down, look up!' 'Keep your legs straight.' 'Point your toes, I said!' The following week, I went onto the high diving board. It was a fixed board that bent down slightly at the front. It looked incredibly high as I stood there, trying to be brave. Slowly, the sounds around me faded away and I felt wrapped in silence. I moved my arms as I had been taught, tried to look up instead of down, and jumped into the air. For a short moment, I felt like I was flying. When I hit the water, my body folded awkwardly and my legs went everywhere. The teacher looked at me with disgust and shook his head. But even he couldn't ruin my excitement. So this is what they mean by 'free as a bird', I thought.

The Traveller

For people like me, who think a comfortable bed, running water, and a good chance of staying alive are very important, the idea of a traveller is both hard to understand and interesting. These are people who have given in to the dangerous attraction of the unknown. They choose to risk their lives by climbing steep, icy mountains that could have avalanches; they sail alone in small boats on huge seas; they will eat insects if there is no better food available; and they can live for months, day and night, surrounded by the mystery and possibility of the unknown.

It is easy to think of these people as strange  and they are  and put them in the same group as other unusual people: hermits, extreme divers, or even writers. We cannot deny they exist, but the strange, uncomfortable world they live in is very different from our normal lives, so we can tell ourselves it's not important. We can just accept it and return thankfully to our world of modern conveniences, happy that the only risks to our health are predictable ones, like running across a busy city street.

SAILING

Jonathan Raban is scared of the sea, saying it is not his natural environment, which might be why he spends so much time on it. He doesn't say he is an expert sailor, but he is clearly a capable one. His main reason for sailing is that, as a writer, he likes to write about his sailing experiences. Sailing always provides exciting events and successes for him to write about.

Raban's small boat has an electronic device that tells sailors their exact location, to within a few metres, anywhere in the world. Although he really likes this tool, he has quite a simple approach to other sailing aids. He believes the invention of the compass was a bad thing, creating a 'basic break in the connection between people and the sea'. Raban says that since it started being used, maybe a thousand years ago, it has become the main thing the person steering looks at. Because of this, they no longer need to watch the waves and sense the sea. The ocean, which was once a place full of activity, has now become just an empty area. Since the helmsman's job is only to keep the boat on a straight path, they can be replaced for long periods by an automatic pilot. This might be why Raban had so much time to observe the waves carefully.
text_C1:
The Allure of the Kitchen

During my university years, I resolved to pursue a career as a chefa decision that was unconventional among my peers. Culinary work was not regarded as a prestigious occupation; on the contrary, it appeared distinctly unappealing. Chefs are known to endure gruelling working conditions: the hours are long, the environment is stressful, the tasks are often repetitive, and the remuneration is modest.

Yet these drawbacks did not deter me. I was discontented with university life, finding the academic demands strenuous and the social atmosphere insular and pretentious. Becoming a chef seemed the ideal antidote to such intellectual and social affectation. It offered a sense of purpose and authenticity that was absent from my college experience.

However, my aspiration to cook was not merely a reaction against student life. It also reflected an aesthetic ideal. This first became apparent during a meal I had at a renowned London restaurantan experience that proved nothing short of revelatory. I can still vividly recall my starter. By the end of the meal, I felt an overwhelming urge to prostrate myself at the feet of the chef in tearful admiration. For days afterward, I felt buoyant and elated.

From that point on, I developed an intense desire to uncover the secrets of this extraordinary art form. I reshaped my student life into an extended period of preparation for my entry into the culinary world. My history degree became a hollow pretence, diverting me from my true vocation. My real education was acquired in a haphazard and incomplete mannerthrough reading cookbooks, exploring markets and delicatessens, and preparing elaborate meals.

Extract from a Novel

The schools swimming instructor was a former drill sergeantcompact and muscular, with tattooed arms. When I requested diving lessons, he instructed me to sit at the pools edge, raise my hands above my head, and roll forward, pushing off with my feet. I repeated this manoeuvre until the session ended. On the following visit, he had me stand upright and dive from the edge. The instructor was a strict disciplinarian, and each time I surfaced, he regarded me with disapproval, barking commands: Dont look downlook up! Keep your legs straight! Point your toes, I said! 

The next week, I ascended the high diving boarda fixed platform with a downward curve at the front. As I stood there, summoning my courage, the height seemed staggering. Gradually, the echoing voices faded, and I felt enveloped in silence. I waved my arms as instructed, focused upward rather than downward, and launched myself into the air. For a fleeting moment, I experienced the sensation of flight. Upon hitting the water, my form collapsed awkwardly, and my legs flailed. The instructor shot me a contemptuous glance and shook his head. Yet even his disapproval could not diminish my exhilaration. So this is what they mean by free as a bird, I thought.

The Traveller

To those of us who prioritise a comfortable bed, running water, and the likelihood of surviving until tomorrow, the phenomenon of the traveller is as baffling as it is fascinating. These are individuals who have yielded to the perilous allure of the unknownwho deliberately risk their lives by scaling the sheer, icy slopes of avalanche-prone mountains; who navigate towering seas alone in fragile vessels; who consume maggots and river insects when no more palatable sustenance is available; and who endure, for months on end, a life overshadowed by the promise and peril of the unfamiliar.

It is tempting to dismiss such individuals as eccentricswhich, admittedly, they areand relegate them to the company of hermits, free-divers, or even writers. While their existence is undeniable, the strange and unsettling world they inhabit lies far beyond our everyday experience, allowing us to dismiss it as irrelevant. We can shrug our shoulders and retreat gratefully to our world of microwave ovens and answering machines, relieved that the only risks to our health are predictable ones, such as making a reckless dash across a busy city street.

Sailing

Jonathan Raban admits to a fear of the sea, acknowledging that it is not his natural elementwhich may explain why he spends so much time on it. Though he makes no claim to being a world-class sailor, he is clearly a competent one. His primary motivation for sailing is that, as a writer, he enjoys writing about his maritime experiences. Sailing reliably supplies both perils and triumphs for his pen to commemorate.

Rabans small vessel is equipped with an electronic device that provides mariners with their precise location, accurate to within a few metres, anywhere on the globe. While he strongly approves of this instrument, his attitude toward other nautical aids is tinged with primitivism. He regards the invention of the compass as a catastrophe, responsible for a fundamental rift in the relationship between humanity and the sea. Raban contends that since its introduction roughly a millennium ago, the compass has become the central focus of the helmsmans attention, with the consequence that he no longer needs to observe the waves or attune himself to the sea. The ocean, once a realm teeming with activity, has been reduced to mere space. Since the task of maintaining a steady course can be delegated for long periods to an autopilot, the helmsmans role is diminished. This may explain why Raban had the opportunity to study the waves so attentively.

original_text:
Work

Theodore Zeldin looks at how our working life could change.

Are you as respected and appreciated as you deserve? Success in a career is no longer enough. Every profession is complaining that it is not properly valued or understood, and even among individuals who have won eminence, there is often bitterness behind the fame. Loving your work, until recently, was enough to make you a member of an envied minority. But now you have to ask yourself what your job is doing to you as a person, to your mind, character and relationships.
This question is crucial. For however brilliant your skills, if they make you a bore, unable to converse with those outside your speciality, if you are so busy with detail that you have no time to acquire wisdom or exercise your imagination or humour, then no amount of status or financial reward will compensate for your inadequacy as a human being.
To counter this, I am trying to discover how work could have the fulfilment of these aspirations as its first priority - instead of treating us as clay to be moulded to suit industrial purposes - and how it could be reconceived to suit us all, both women and men. It would have to be not just a way of creating wealth, but a worthwhile style of life, a path to a fuller existence, to the discovery of unsuspected talents and to a wider variety of human contacts.
However, this remodelling would not mean abolishing unemployment. This is too simple a goal, because the more people are educated, the more they demand jobs that are life-enhancing, interesting and useful. A lifetime of work has to be seen as a work of art, with the fulfilled individual at its centre.
Even the middle-class professions, however, no longer have the liberating appeal they once had. Doctors are often more stressed than their patients and complain about the failure of clinical medicine. Accountants, despite unprecedented influence, are troubled by doubts about their profession's ethics. Most architects never get the chance to exercise their imaginations freely. Administrators are paralysed by their own bureaucracy. The middle managers, who once gloried in their status, are, as a European study reveals, losing their conviction.
Meanwhile, the business corporations and public institutions in which these people work are slimming. The panaceas of decentralised decision-making, increasing skills and performance-related rewards have not succeeded in winning commitment from employees. In Britain, only 8 per cent of employees 'are strongly of the view that their values and those of their organisations are very similar'.
I have embarked on an investigation of a wide range of occupations, one by one, to see how each shapes and sometimes destroys those in it. I have studied how the notion of what humans are capable of has been expanded in different civilisations, and how courage can be manufactured. I have applied my method to the major preoccupations of our time - happiness, love, friendship and respect.
Having looked at those areas, I am now focusing on the search for more satisfying ways of earning a living. There is no shortage of experts devoting themselves to prolonging the life and increasing the income of corporations and institutions. But auditing our finances is not enough: we need to make an audit of ourselves as human beings too, and discover with what sort of people we want to spend our lives.
How many of us can say that we are fully alive at work? How many of us are really part-time slaves - theoretically having the right to escape from our drudgery, but in reality virtual prisoners of our qualifications and careers, used as instruments by others, working not so that we might become better people, but because we can see no other option?
Take hotel workers as an example, since 10 per cent of the working population is now in the 'hospitality industry'. The amount of unused potential is unbelievable. Many highly intelligent and lively people put up with low prestige, low salaries and long hours.
This is because there has been no serious rethinking of what a hotel is since the days of the Ritz, with its nineteenth-century idea of luxury. A hotel is not just a place where travellers sleep, but a United Nations in miniature. People from all over the world meet at hotels, though they usually pass each other in silence.
A large proportion of hotel staff are foreigners too, keen to learn a new language and discover a new civilisation, but they have the most superficial relations with their guests. Hotels could be cultural centres, active intermediaries between the guest and the city, genuine hosts bringing together people who have not met. Hoteliers could use the knowledge of the many students they employ, instead of giving them only menial tasks.
If they paid closer attention to their staff's deepest ambitions, they would realise that there were many other services that hotels could provide. But they are restrained by the accountants, who say that firms, in order to maximise their profits, should concentrate on one core activity.
The time has come to rethink what this term denotes - from a human, not just a financial angle - and to move on from traditional categorisations. For me, work is a relationship. Now that many people are not content with relations based on obedience, and regard work as an assertion of independence or temperament, they must be given a chance to design their own jobs, and choose their own colleagues, even their customers, within the limits of practicality and profitability.
This means that they have to know how to converse across the boundaries of professional jargon, with minds that may at first seem quite alien. Everybody is clear about the importance of communication, but it is a very different thing from conversation, and traditional conversation is very different from the new kind of conversation which people feel the lack of today.
This is a more intimate encounter, which creates a bond of respect between the participants, and is valued as a way of getting inside another person's skin, with the likelihood that one will be changed by the experience. It is more than a relaxation, because it is the most effective means of establishing equality. Every time you have a conversation which achieves that, the world is changed by a minute amount.
text_A1:
Theodore Zeldin thinks about work. How can work change?

Do you feel good at your job? Many people do not feel happy at work. They want more. They want to feel good about what they do.

Work should help you be a better person. It should help you learn new things and meet new people. Work should be good for your life.

But many jobs are not like this. For example, doctors feel a lot of stress. Accountants worry about doing the right thing. Many people in offices feel stuck.

Companies want to make money. But workers want more. They want to feel that their work is important.

Theodore Zeldin looks at many jobs. He wants to see how work can be better. He thinks work should help people be happy and have good friends.

How many people feel happy at work? Many people feel like they have to work. They do not have another choice.

Think about people who work in hotels. Many are smart and friendly. But their jobs are often not good. They work long hours for little money.

Hotels can be more than a place to sleep. They can be a place where people from different countries meet and talk. Hotel workers can help guests learn about the city and meet new people.

Work is like a relationship between people. People want to choose what they do and who they work with. They want to talk to others and understand them.

Talking is important. Good talking helps people understand each other. It can make the world a little better.
text_B1:
Theodore Zeldin thinks about how our jobs could be different.

Do you feel that people respect and value you enough? Being successful in your job is not the only important thing now. People in many jobs feel that others don't understand or appreciate their work. Even famous people are sometimes unhappy. Before, if you loved your job, you were lucky. But now you need to think about what your job does to you as a person. How does it change your mind, your character, and your relationships with others?

This is very important. You might have great skills, but if your job makes you boring, or if you can't talk to people who do different work, or if you are always busy with small details and have no time to think about bigger ideas or be creative, then no amount of money or a good job title will make you a happy person.

To help with this, I want to find out how work can make us feel happy and complete. Work should not just use us for business. It should be changed to fit all people, women and men. Work should not only be about making money. It should be a good way to live, help us find new talents, and meet different kinds of people.

But changing work does not just mean giving jobs to everyone who is unemployed. This is too simple. When people are more educated, they want jobs that are interesting and make life better. We should think of our working life as a kind of art, with the happy person at the center.

Even good jobs like being a doctor or an accountant are not as good as they used to be. Doctors are often very stressed. Accountants worry if their job is always right. Most architects cannot be as creative as they want. Managers feel stuck by rules. A study in Europe shows that middle managers are losing confidence in their jobs.

At the same time, the companies and organizations where these people work are getting smaller. Ideas like letting workers make more decisions, teaching them new skills, or paying them for good work have not made employees feel more connected to their company. In Britain, only 8% of workers feel that their personal values are the same as their company's values.

I am studying many different jobs to see how they change the people who do them, sometimes in a bad way. I have looked at how different cultures have different ideas about what people can do, and how people can become brave. I have used this way of thinking to look at important parts of life like happiness, love, friendship, and respect.

Now, I am looking for better ways to earn money. There are many experts who help companies live longer and make more money. But checking our money is not enough. We also need to check ourselves as people. We need to think about what kind of people we want to be and who we want to spend our time with.

How many of us feel truly alive at work? How many of us are like part-time slaves? We think we can leave our boring jobs, but really we feel trapped by our education and careers. We are used by other people. We work not to become better, but because we don't know what else to do.

Let's think about hotel workers. Ten percent of workers now work in hotels. There is so much talent that is not used. Many very smart and friendly people work for low pay and long hours.

This is because nobody has really thought about what a hotel could be since a long time ago. A hotel is not just a place to sleep. It is like a small United Nations. People from all over the world stay in hotels, but they usually don't talk to each other.

Many hotel workers are also from other countries. They want to learn a new language and learn about a new culture, but they don't have deep conversations with the guests. Hotels could be places of culture. They could help guests learn about the city. They could bring people together. Hotel managers could use the knowledge of the students who work for them, instead of only giving them boring jobs.

If hotel managers listened to what their workers really want, they would see that hotels could offer many new services. But the people who manage the money say that to make the most profit, a company should only do one main thing.

It is time to think again about what work means - from a human point of view, not just a money point of view. We need to move past old ideas about jobs. For me, work is a relationship. Many people today don't want a relationship where they just obey. They see work as a way to be independent and be themselves. They should have a chance to design their own jobs and choose who they work with, and even who their customers are, if it is possible and makes money.

This means that people need to know how to talk to others who are different from them, even if they use different words. Everyone knows that communication is important, but it is not the same as conversation. And normal conversation is different from the new kind of conversation that people need today.

This new conversation is more personal. It creates respect between people. It is a way to really understand another person, and you might change because of it. It is more than just relaxing. It is the best way to make people feel equal. Every time you have a conversation like this, you change the world a little bit.

If they paid more attention to their staff's real ambitions, they would see that hotels could offer many other services. But they are held back by accountants, who say that companies should focus on one main activity to make the most profit.

The time has come to rethink what this idea meansfrom a human perspective, not just a financial oneand to move beyond traditional job categories. For me, work is a relationship. Now that many people are not satisfied with jobs based on obedience, and see work as a way to express their independence or personality, they should have the chance to design their own jobs, choose their colleagues, and even select their customers, as long as it is practical and profitable.

This means they need to know how to talk across professional boundaries, with people who may at first seem very different. Everyone understands the importance of communication, but it is not the same as conversationand traditional conversation is different from the deeper, more meaningful kind that people miss today.

This kind of conversation is more personal; it creates a bond of respect and allows you to understand another person's experience, with the possibility that you will be changed by it. It is more than just relaxation, because it is a powerful way to create equality. Every time you have a conversation like that, the world changes a little.

Screen Learning

A few days ago I noticed my six-year-old eating noodles in a funny way. He was pulling them up with his teeth while trying to look fierce. 'I'm a little dinosaur,' he said. He was play-acting a scene from a recent TV programme, so I quizzed him about what he remembered about dinosaurs. The answer was, not a lot.
There is a modish rush to embrace internet and computer learning, but is learning via a screen a good method? One writer tells how he tried out an interactive programme with his son. The father diligently read the words while the son fiddled with the pictures. 'Had he spent ten minutes in front of a book, he might possibly have learned something,' said his father.
Television, as my son and his noodles demonstrate, is an impressionistic, suggestive medium. Research about television and learning shows that learning goes on in a learning environment where dialogue is taking place with teachers or parents. It needs to be mediated. There is nothing wrong with harnessing new technology to teach our children, but there is still a big role for formal education.

Hollywood

By 1918, four-fifths of the film-making capacity of the world had relocated to Hollywood. Locals disapproved, seeing their suburb of Los Angeles infected by these new vulgarians. But in the end snobbery yielded to the true American value, success. And success is the box-office gross. Hollywood knows a good film when it sees one: one that may make a star, but must make somebody's fortune.
In less than a century, Hollywood has grown from a toffee-nosed village to a town as famous as New York, Rome or Paris. And physically, of course, it has changed beyond recognition: a century ago, you would walk through orange groves to the village store. Yet in a way, it is still a village - parochial, with limited horizons - just a little bit of Los Angeles. For all who live and work in it, there is one topic of conversation - films: how much they have made, who is dating whom, who's been stabbed in the back, who is 'attached' to which project. Those who have been successful often try to get away: to work there, but live somewhere else. Yet it is still the one place in the world to which almost everyone who is anyone in show-business (and plenty who agent) eventually gravitates.

Photography

Photography was invented by nineteenth century artists as an art form for their own purposes. These men were seeking a lasting, literal record of their visual surroundings and they found it. The new combination of illumination, lens, shutter, and flat surface coated with chemicals sensitive to light produced images more lasting, more convincing in their reality, and more richly detailed than painters could produce manually in weeks and months of effort. This alone was enough to throw consternation into the ranks of fellow artists; and, after their first reaction of pleasure in a new kind of image, art critics rallied with the haughty charge that photography was not, and could not be, an art. The actual world in which we live had too strong a grip on photography, they said, and pictures so dependent upon mechanical means could not be called acts of man's creative imagination.
Despite the critics, photographers knew that they had found a new art form, a new mode of expression. They used the new tools as other artists before and after them have used brush and pencil - to interpret the world, to present a vision of nature and its structure as well as the things and the people in it.

Book Illustration

During the black-and-white era of book illustration it was axiomatic that each and every children's book called for some form of illustration. This extended to the large category of novels for the upper reading ages, which was to suffer progressive attrition as print runs shortened. The level of activity in all areas of children's publishing remained considerable, but it was run predominantly as a low-budget operation for most of the period and as such encouraged a fair amount of routine and mediocre work, although the finest artists seldom submitted less than their professional best. Therefore, the black-and-white archive is part junk shop, part treasure house, a wonderful place for research or for browsing, and one in which to make immediate finds or to begin to re-evaluate a fertile artistic period. The real treasures are bound to return to public display, whether enduringly through reissues of individual titles and new publications about the artists who illustrated them - or from time to time in the form of exhibitions of original books and drawings. There are signs that, after a period of neglect, this is starting to happen and the familiar processes of stylistic rehabilitation can be seen to be at work. In due course, an enterprising publisher will doubtlessly see the potential for a series of classic children's book illustrations from this period either in facsimile reprint, or in freshly-designed editions using the original artwork where it survives.

original_text:
Writing Reviews

Frank Kermode examines the craft of review-writing from a practitioner's point of view.

Most reviews are written and circulated under conditions which ensure that they have a very short active life. There are deadlines, there are restrictions, normally quite severe, on their length; and when published they claim houseroom only for as long as the newspaper they are printed in - a day or a week, at most a month. Moreover, the literary status of reviews tends to be settled by their ephemerality. It is usually supposed, not only by the public but, quite often, by the writers themselves, that reviewing is work that nobody would do if there weren't some reason -- shortage of cash would he cited most often, though another good reason is that you can't work all day on a novel or a 'serious'
book of any sort - which prevents them from occupying their time with something more valuable.
Yet reviewing is a skilled and multi-faceted job. It is one thing to be bright, brisk and summarily fair in the six or eight hundred words of an ordinary newspaper review, quite another to control, without looseness of argument, the six or eight thousand words sometimes allowed by international journals. And the fifteen hundred words of a leading piece in the weekly magazines present some of the problems of both short and long. Not that length is the only consideration. For one thing, the reviewer obviously needs to think about the probable audience, the weekend skimmer at one end of the scale, the person already interested enough in the subject to tackle a serious review-article at the other. Finally, a reviewer needs to know quite a bit about quite a number of things; and must be able to write prose that intelligent people can understand and enjoy. It follows almost infallibly that the reviewer will be somebody who writes other things besides reviews.
The American novelist Johh Updike, who rather looks down on criticism -- 'hugging the shore' he calls it - nevertheless enjoys some coastal reviewing in the intervals between his transoceanic novel-writing. Understandably reluctant to allow even his less ambitious voyages to go without any permanent record, he gathers together his every review, however short, into volumes with mildly self-deprecating titles. It might be thought that lesser persons should accept ephemerality as the penalty appropriate to their coastal caution, but it is hand to see why, if they can get away with it, they shouldn't be allowed to enjoy the measure of permanence, and the measure of vanity, proper to their station, especially if they believe that some of their best writing has been 'buried' in reviews. I admit to feeling this about my own work.
My own principal occupation has been academic, and most of my 'serious' books are recognisably academic products, the sort of thing professors like, and are expected to do as part of their jobs. However, the English-speaking world (I think fortunately) acknowledges nothing comparable to the sharp distinction people from other cultures make between reviewing and literary study -- and so with us it is quite usual for the same people to do both. The days are gone when other academics reviled reviewer-professors for unseemly self-display, or waste of academic time, or betrayal of the dignity of their institutions. And complaints from non-professors, to the effect that the professors are taking the bread out of their mouths, are also less common than they were, partly because there is so much more reviewing nowadays that practically everyone can have some, partly, no doubt, because the bread is often such a meagre ration.
My own view is that these arrangements are good for both readers -- since they can be fairly certain the reviewer has at least some idea what he is talking about -- and professors, if only because the work helps to keep them sane. It also reminds them that they have a duty, easily neglected, to make themselves intelligible to non-professors. When talking among themselves they may feel some need to be impressively arcane, but when addressing intelligent non-professors they need to make sure they are communicating effectively.
Finally, it is clear that for a variety of reasons, and despite all that can be said to dignify it, reviewing must be a secondary occupation. It is something you can only do well enough if you are also doing something else well enough.
text_A2:
Writing Reviews

Frank Kermode writes about how to write reviews. He has written many reviews himself.

Most reviews are written quickly and are not read for a long time. They are often short because newspapers and magazines only give a little space. People read them for a day, a week, or maybe a month, and then forget them. Many people think that writing reviews is not very important work. They think writers only do it to make money or when they need a break from writing bigger books.

But writing a good review is not easy. It is a skill. A short review for a newspaper is different from a long review for a special magazine. A writer must think about who will read the review. Some readers want a quick summary. Other readers want more details. A reviewer must know about many things and must write in a way that is easy for people to understand. Because of this, most people who write reviews also write other things, like books.

The famous American writer John Updike sometimes wrote reviews between writing his big novels. He collected his reviews into books. Some people might think that short reviews should be forgotten, but if a writer is proud of their work, why shouldn't they save it? I feel this way about my own reviews.

My main job has been as a university teacher. I have written serious books for other teachers. In the English-speaking world, it is normal for teachers to also write reviews. In the past, some people did not like this. They thought teachers should not write for newspapers. But now this happens a lot, and there are many reviews for everyone to write.

I think this is good for everyone. Readers can trust that the reviewer knows about the topic. For teachers, it is good because it helps them stay connected to the real world. It reminds them to write clearly so that people who are not teachers can understand them. When teachers talk to each other, they sometimes use difficult words. But when they write for everyone, they need to be clear.

In the end, reviewing is a job you do on the side. You can only be a good reviewer if you are also good at another, bigger job.

Writing Reviews

Frank Kermode looks at how to write reviews from the point of view of someone who writes them.

Most reviews are written quickly and do not last long. They have short deadlines and must not be too long. When they are printed in a newspaper or magazine, people only read them for a short timea day, a week, or at most a month. Because of this, many people think reviews are not very important. Often, people believe that writers only write reviews because they need money, or because they cannot work on a bigger book all the time.

But writing a good review is a skill. It is one thing to write a short review of 600 to 800 words for a newspaper. It is another to write a much longer review of 6,000 to 8,000 words for a serious magazine. A review of 1,500 words for a weekly magazine has its own challenges too. Of course, length is not the only thing to think about. The writer must also think about the reader. Some readers just want a quick summary, while others want a detailed review. A reviewer needs to know about many things and must write in a way that is clear and interesting for intelligent people. Because of this, most reviewers also write other things, not just reviews.

The American writer John Updike does not think very highly of criticism. He calls it "hugging the shore." Still, he writes reviews between working on his big novels. He likes to collect his reviews into books, even the short ones, so they are not forgotten. Maybe other, less famous writers should also be able to keep their reviews in books, especially if they think some of their best writing is in those reviews. I feel this way about my own review writing.

My main job has been as a university teacher. Most of my serious books are academicthe kind that professors write. In English-speaking countries, people do not make a big difference between writing reviews and doing academic work. The same people often do both. In the past, other professors would criticize professor-reviewers for showing off or wasting time. But this does not happen much now. Also, other writers used to complain that professors were taking their work, but this is also less common. There are more reviews to write now, so many people can do it, and the pay is often not very high.

I think this situation is good for readers because they can trust that the reviewer knows something about the subject. It is also good for professors because it helps them stay connected to the real world. It reminds them to write in a way that everyone can understand, not just other professors. When they talk to other professors, they might use difficult language, but when they write for everyone, they need to be clear.

In the end, it is clear that reviewing must be a second job. You can only do it well if you are also good at doing something else.

original_text:
Sand

Much as I admire sands miraculous ability to be transformed into useful objects like glass and concrete, I am not a great fan of it in its natural state. To me it is primarily a hostile barrier that stands between a seaside car park and the water itself. It blows in your face, gets in your sandwiches, and swallows vital objects like car keys and coins. When you are wet it adheres to you like 'stucco', and cannot be shifted, even with a fireman's hose. But, and here's the strange thing, the moment you step onto a beach towel, climb into a car or walk across a recently vacuumed carpet, it pours off you. For days afterwards, you tip mysteriously undiminishing piles of it onto the floor every time you take on your shoes, and spray the vicinity with lots more when you peel off your socks. Sand stays with you for longer than many contagious diseases. No, you can keep sand, as far as I am concerned.

Lock and Key

The search for a safe home, for privacy and security, has existed ever since human beings first built a permanent homestead. The rope-lifted beam behind the door may have given way to an electronic lock triggered by a plastic card with more combinations than there are atoms in the universe, but the urge to shut out the 'bad guys' remains. The appeal of a lock and key is, to some extent, psychological. Recently, various companies have experimented with computerised locking systems, where smart cards, swiped through a 'reader', control electronic locks by means of a digital command. But people don't like them. You may be prepared to put up with it at work, but at home, everyone wants the reassurance of turning a physical key in a lock. As a result, when one locksmith company developed a new electronic system, they made sure they incorporated a proper metal key into the device.

Modern Art

I was nervous about visiting the new Tate Modern gallery as, like many people, I can make head nor tail of modern art. I know I quite like some of it, furry things in particular, neon light sculptures and massive photographs. Perhaps if I were better informed about it, I'd have an opinion on more things. There again, yours not meant to set about it in a school-essay way. The point is not to grasp art, but to let it communicate with you. This is a splendid idea but one that never worked for me in practice. But this new gallery has tried to give the visitor a genuine insight into the whys and wherefores of the works. The first thing I noticed were the labels, proper labels that set a work in context and actually told you what it was trying to say. Instead of staring blankly at the pictures as I used to, these nuggets of information helped me understand.

It blows into your face, gets into your food, and you can lose small but important things like car keys in it. When you are wet, the sand sticks to your skin and it is very hard to wash off. But the strange thing is, as soon as you stand on a towel, get into a car, or walk on a clean carpet, the sand falls off you. For days after, every time you take off your shoes, sand falls onto the floor. It seems like there is always more sand in your shoes and socks. Sand stays with you for a very long time. No, I think I can live without sand.

**Lock and Key**

People have always wanted a safe home, a private and secure place. This started when humans first built houses to live in. A long time ago, people used a heavy piece of wood to lock a door. Now we have electronic locks that you open with a plastic card. These cards can have millions of different codes. But the reason is the same: we want to keep bad people out. Liking a lock and key is partly a feeling in your mind. Recently, some companies have tried new computer locking systems. You use a smart card in a machine to open an electronic lock. But people don't really like these systems. You might use one at work, but at home, everyone likes the feeling of turning a real key in a lock. Because of this, when one company made a new electronic lock, they made sure it also used a normal metal key.

**Modern Art**

I felt a bit worried about going to the new Tate Modern gallery. This is because, like a lot of people, I often don't understand modern art. I know that I like some of it, especially things that are furry, sculptures made from neon lights, and very big photographs. Maybe if I knew more about it, I would understand more pieces. But you are not supposed to study it like you do for a school project. The idea is not to completely understand the art, but to let the art talk to you. I think this is a great idea, but it has never really worked for me. However, this new gallery has tried to help visitors really understand why the art was made and what it means. The first thing I saw were the information signs. They were good signs that explained the situation when the art was made and told you what the artist wanted to say. Before, I used to just look at the pictures without understanding. Now, these small pieces of information helped me understand them.

original_text:
Observing Lions

In the popular imagination, lions hunting for food present a marvel of group choreography: in the dying light of sunset, a band of stealthy cats springs forth from the shadows like trained assassins and surrounds its unsuspecting prey. The lions seem to be archetypal social animals, rising above petty dissension to work together towards a common goal - in this case, their next meal. But after spending many years observing these creatures in the wild, we have acquired a less exalted view. 
When we started our research in 1978, we hoped to discover why lions teamed up to hunt, rear cubs and among other things, scare off rivals with chorused roars. If the ultimate success of an animals behaviour is measured by its lifetime production of surviving offspring, then cooperation does not necessarily pay: if an animal is too generous, its companions benefit at its expense. Why, then, did not the evolutionary rules of genetic self-interest seem to apply to lions?
We confidently assumed that we would be able to resolve that issue in two to three years. But lions are supremely adept at doing nothing. To the list of inert noble gases, including krypton, argon and neon, we would add lion. Thus it has taken a variety of research measures to uncover clues about the cats behaviour. Because wild lions can live up to 18 years, the answers to our questions are only now becoming clear. 

Pop Music Review

The release of Bedrock's third album was more than just a landmark in the career of a talented but hitherto precarious band. New Life launched a movement that effectively redesigned the specification of rock music in this country for the rest of the decade. Out went the earnest angst, plain-shirted drabness and overdriven guitars of a previous era; in came a lighter blend of melodious homegrown styles. A mix of social observation and strident anger mingled easily here with the sound of fairground organs and northern brass bands. Humour and irony were well to the fore, as were the voices that felt no need to disguise their origins.
The album showed Bedrock to be skilful magpie collectors and observers, and a cunningly versatile team of songwriters. At their most obvious, they went larkily after traditional English preoccupations such as sunbathing and Sunday afternoons. But the album's real strength lay in the gentle melancholy depths it plumbed on tracks such as 'So Low', a gorgeous unfurling tune loosely hung around the theme of meteorology, and 'To the Brink', a ballad that allowed no smirking at the back. The beauty of New Life is its consistently sky-high quality - 16 tracks with absolutely no filler remains an unsurpassed record in the era of loiteringly long CDs.

Extract from an autobiography

As a child I was always fascinated by stories of 'The Sibyl', those mysteriously wise women who wielded such influence in the ancient world. To begin with, I only knew of the existence of one who appeared in a tale my mother had told me. An old woman of Cumae offered Tarquin, King of Rome, nine books for 300 gold pieces. He refused and she burnt three of them, offering him six for the same price. When he refused, she again burnt three books. He bought the remaining three for the full 300 gold pieces. 
I realised even then that there was a profound truth hidden in the story - a lesson in salesmanship and in life. I was sometimes a lonely only child. I used to ask to play with other children and be refused. My mother told me to do something so interesting that all the other kids would beg to join me. It worked. It was another lesson that I've never forgotten.
When I was given the chance to write a travel book, I had to look for something that I could bear to find out about, something that was relevant to my life. I'm a reluctant traveller - at the first opportunity I sent my editor a very long list of places I wasn't prepared to go to. When it comes down to it, I'm only interested in ruins, because the travel I like is the travel of the mind through time.

What becomes of your manuscript?

When you submit your manuscript it will most likely join a heap waiting for someone to sort and sift before it topples over - the so-called slush pile. The someone is usually either the editorial department junior (i.e. under 18) or an old hand who comes in a couple of mornings a week and is paid by the hour. Neither of these has much influence, but they are basically on your side and out to discover something original - the junior to make his or her name and acquire an author of their own if they are lucky, the old hand to justify continuing freelance employment.
If they think your novel is promising, they will pass it on to a more senior editor and eventually it will surface at an acquisition meeting. The championing editor will not only have to justify accepting your novel on the grounds of intrinsic merit and potential sales, but also say whether you as an author seem to be a long-term prospect (which you will have assured them of in your letter). Also the question is raised of how promotable you are likely to be - an important factor - when a new novel needs all the help it can get. To this end, publishers often like to meet a potential author before clinching the offer.

original_text:
Enough Sleep?

Tiredness, it is often claimed, has become the modern condition. As the richer, busier countries have grown, so sleeplessness and anxiety have also grown in the popular psyche. Research in the USA has found 40 million Americans to be chronically affected, and some recent best-selling novels in Britain have featured insomniacs as protagonists, or sleep-research laboratories as their settings.
Part of this interest is in sleep in general: in its rhythms, its uses and in problems with sleeping. But a central preoccupation remains. 'People need more sleep,' says one leading sleep researcher. 'People cut back on sleep when they're busy. They get up too early to avoid the rush hour.'
Recently, a sleep researcher tried an experiment. He offered his subjects the opposite of the modern routine. 'I allowed them to sleep for up to 14 hours a night for a month. It took them three weeks to reach an equilibrium of eight-and-a-quarter hours. That indicates a great rebound of sleep - sleep that they hadn't been getting!'
In Europe, such propositions are perhaps most thoroughly tested in a small unassuming building on a university campus in the English Midlands. The university sleep research laboratory has investigated, among many subjects, the effects of fatigue on sailors, the effects of airpot noise on sleepers, and the dangers of motorway driving for flagging drivers.
For guinea pigs, they advertise in the student newspapers. Subjects are picked up by taxi, paid PS5 an hour, and asked to adjust their sleeping patterns according to instructions. Dr Louise Reyner provides reassurance: 'Some people are quite worried, because you're putting electrodes on their heads, and they think you can see what they're dreaming or thinking.'
In fact, the laboratory's interest is more physical. In a darkened room stands a motorway simulator, the front section of car facing a wide projection screen. The subjects are always told to arrive at 2pm, in the body's natural mid-afternoon lull, after a short night's sleep or no sleep at all. The projector is switched on and they are asked to drive, while answering questions. An endless road rolls ahead, sunlight glares; and the air is warm.
The young men all deny they are going to fall asleep. Dr Reyner has a video recording of one trying not to. At first the person at the wheel is very upright, wet and bleary eyes determinedly fixed on the windscreen. Then he begins to blink briefly, every now and again; then for longer, and more often, with a slight drop of the head. Each nod grows heavier than the last. The blinks become a 10-second blackout. Every time, he jerks awake as if nothing has happened. But the car, by the second or third occasion, has shot off the carriageway.
A coffee might have helped. Two cups, Dr Reyner says, even after no sleep at all, can make you a safe driver for half an hour or more. She recommends a whole basket of alertness products: tablets, energy drinks, caffeinated chewing gum. Shift workers, she is quite sure, could probably use them.
But apart from these findings, what else do know about human sleep with any kind of certainty? It is known that humans sleep, like other mammals, according to a daily cycle. Once asleep, they switch between four different stages of unconsciousness, from stage one sleep, the shallowest, to stage four, the deepest. When dreams occur, which is usually during the lightest sleep, the brain paralyses the body except for the hands and eyelids, thus preventing injuries.
Beyond this, certainties blur into theories. It is often suggested, for example, that sleep repairs body tissue, or restores muscles, or rests the frontal section of the brain that controls speech and creativity. But all of this may happen more quickly during relaxed wakefulness, so no one is really sure.
However, there is a strong degree of certainty among scientists that women seep for half an hour longer than men, and that older people require less sleep, though they don't know why. When asked what sleep is for, some sleep researchers reply in cosmic terms: 'Sleep is a tactic to travel through time without injury.'
Moreover, people may have had different sleep patterns in the past. A history professor has investigated nocturnal British life between 1500 and 1850 and discovered that sleeping routines were very different. People went to bed at nine or ten, then woke up after midnight, after what they called their 'first sleep', stayed awake for an hour, and then had their 'morning sleep'.
The interlude was a haven for reflection, remembering dreams, or even night-time thieving. The poorest were the greatest beneficiaries of this quiet time, fleetingly freed from the constraints and labours that ruled their day-time existence.
By the 17th century, however, as artificial light became more common, the rich began to switch to the more concentrated, and economically more efficient, mode of recuperation that we follow today. Two centuries later, the industrial revolution pushed back the dusk for everyone except some country-dwellers, by making most people work longer hours in lighted buildings.
Yet beyond Europe and America, the old pattern was widespread until quite recently, and according to a leading anthropologist, in some non-western settings there are still no rigid bedtimes. People go to bed for a few hours, and then get up again. The idea of a night's solid sleep does not apply. For certain tribal societies, human and animal noises and the need to supervise the fire and watch out for predators combine to make continuous sleep impossible. It seems that people all round the world are badly in need of sleep.
text_A2:
Do You Get Enough Sleep?

Many people today say they feel tired. In busy countries, more people have problems with sleep and feel worried. In the USA, 40 million people always feel tired. Some popular books in Britain are about people who cannot sleep.

People are interested in sleep. They want to know why we sleep and why some people have sleep problems. One expert says, "People need more sleep. When they are busy, they sleep less. They wake up early to miss the busy traffic."

A sleep expert did a test. He let people sleep for 14 hours every night for one month. After three weeks, they only needed eight and a quarter hours of sleep. This shows they needed to catch up on lost sleep.

In England, there is a small sleep lab at a university. They study how tiredness affects sailors, how airport noise affects sleep, and the dangers of driving when tired.

The lab finds people for tests through student newspapers. They take them by taxi, pay them 5 an hour, and ask them to change their sleep times. Dr. Louise Reyner says, "Some people worry because we put wires on their heads. They think we can see their dreams."

The lab is more interested in the body. In a dark room, there is a car simulator. People sit in the car and watch a big screen. They are told to come at 2 pm, when people often feel sleepy. They drive on the screen and answer questions. The road is long, the sun is bright, and the room is warm.

The young men always say they will not fall asleep. But Dr. Reyner has a video of one man trying to stay awake. At first, he sits up straight and looks at the road. Then he blinks a lot and his head drops. Soon, he closes his eyes for ten seconds. Each time, he wakes up quickly, but the car has already left the road.

Coffee can help. Dr. Reyner says two cups of coffee can make you a safe driver for half an hour, even with no sleep. She suggests other things to help you stay awake, like pills, energy drinks, and gum with caffeine. She thinks people who work at night could use them.

What else do we know about sleep? We know people sleep every day, like other animals. When we sleep, we go through four stages, from light sleep to deep sleep. We dream during light sleep. When we dream, the brain stops the body from moving, so we don't get hurt.

Scientists have ideas about why we sleep. Some think sleep helps fix the body or rest the brain. But they are not sure, because the body may fix itself faster when we are awake but resting.

Scientists are sure that women sleep 30 minutes longer than men, and older people need less sleep, but they don't know why. When asked why we sleep, one expert said, "Sleep is a way to pass time safely."

In the past, people slept differently. A history professor found that between 1500 and 1850, people in Britain went to bed at 9 or 10 pm. They woke up after midnight for an hour, then went back to sleep until morning.

This hour awake was a time to think, remember dreams, or sometimes steal. Poor people liked this quiet time because they were free from their daily work.

By the 1600s, rich people started to sleep all night without waking up, because they had more lights. Two hundred years later, the industrial revolution made most people work longer hours in buildings with lights, so they also slept all night.

Outside of Europe and America, many people had the old sleep pattern until recently. In some places, people still do not sleep all night. They sleep for a few hours, then get up. They cannot sleep for a long time because they need to listen for animals and watch the fire. It seems people everywhere need more sleep.

Then he starts to blink a lot, and his head drops a little. Each time his head drops, it gets worse. Soon, he closes his eyes for ten seconds. Each time, he wakes up suddenly, but by then, the car has already left the road.

Coffee could help. Dr. Reyner says two cups of coffee, even with no sleep, can make you drive safely for about half an hour. She suggests other things to help you stay awake, like pills, energy drinks, or gum with caffeine. She thinks people who work at night could use these.

But what else do we know for sure about sleep? We know that people, like other animals, sleep as part of a daily cycle. When we sleep, we go through four stages, from light sleep to very deep sleep. We usually dream during light sleep. When we dream, the brain stops the body from moving (except for the eyes and hands) so we don't get hurt.

Other ideas about sleep are less certain. Some people think sleep helps fix the body, build muscles, or rest the part of the brain used for talking and ideas. But these things might also happen when we are resting while awake, so no one is sure.

Scientists are quite sure that women sleep about 30 minutes longer than men, and older people need less sleep, though they don't know why. When asked why we sleep, some experts say, "Sleep is a way to pass through time safely."

In the past, people may have slept differently. A history professor studied life at night in Britain from 1500 to 1850. He found that people went to bed at 9 or 10pm, woke up after midnight (after their "first sleep"), stayed awake for about an hour, and then went back to sleep for their "morning sleep."

This time awake was used for thinking, remembering dreams, or sometimes for stealing. Poor people benefited most from this quiet time, free for a short while from their hard daily lives.

By the 17th century, as artificial light became more common, rich people started sleeping all through the night, which was better for work. Two hundred years later, the Industrial Revolution made most people work longer hours in lit buildings, so everyone except some people in the countryside started sleeping through the night.

Outside Europe and America, the old sleep pattern was common until not long ago. An expert says that in some non-Western places, people still don't have fixed bedtimes. They sleep for a few hours, get up, and then sleep again. The idea of sleeping all night doesn't exist there. In some tribes, noises from people and animals, and the need to watch the fire and look out for danger, make it impossible to sleep without waking up. It seems that people everywhere really need more sleep.
text_B2:
Are We Getting Enough Sleep?

Many people claim that tiredness has become a common condition in modern life. As wealthier and busier nations develop, sleeplessness and anxiety have also increased in the general population. Research in the United States has found that 40 million Americans are chronically affected by sleep problems. In Britain, several recent best-selling novels have featured characters who suffer from insomnia or have been set in sleep research laboratories.

There is growing interest in sleep itselfits patterns, functions, and common disorders. However, a central concern remains. According to one leading sleep researcher, "People need more sleep. When they are busy, they reduce their sleep time. They wake up too early to avoid rush hour traffic."

Recently, a sleep researcher conducted an experiment. He allowed participants to sleep up to 14 hours per night for an entire month. It took three weeks for them to stabilize at around eight hours of sleep per night. This suggests they had been experiencing significant sleep deprivation.

In Europe, such theories are tested extensively in a modest building at a university in central England. The university's sleep laboratory has studied various topics, including how fatigue affects sailors, how airport noise disturbs sleep, and the dangers of motorway driving when tired.

The laboratory recruits volunteers through student newspaper advertisements. Participants are collected by taxi, paid 5 per hour, and instructed to adjust their sleep schedules according to the study requirements. Dr. Louise Reyner reassures them: "Some people feel anxious because we attach electrodes to their heads. They worry we can see their dreams or thoughts, but we cannot."

The laboratory's focus is primarily physical rather than mental. In a darkened room, there is a motorway simulator consisting of a car's front section facing a large projection screen. Participants are always scheduled to arrive at 2 p.m., during the body's natural afternoon energy dip, particularly after limited or no sleep. They are asked to drive in the simulator while answering questions. An endless road appears ahead, with bright sunlight and warm air in the room.

The young male participants always insist they will not fall asleep. Dr. Reyner has a video recording of one man struggling to stay awake. Initially, he sits upright with his eyes fixed on the windshield. Then he begins blinking briefly and occasionally, followed by longer and more frequent blinks as his head gradually drops. Each time his head falls, it becomes harder to lift. Eventually, his eyes remain closed for up to ten seconds. Although he jerks awake each time, by the second or third occurrence, the car has already left the road.

Coffee might have prevented this. Dr. Reyner states that two cups of coffee, even after no sleep, can maintain safe driving for half an hour or longer. She recommends various alertness products including tablets, energy drinks, and caffeinated chewing gum. She believes shift workers could benefit from using these products.

But what else do we truly understand about human sleep? We know that humans, like other mammals, follow a daily sleep cycle. During sleep, people move through four different stages of unconsciousness, from the lightest (stage one) to the deepest (stage four). Dreams typically occur during the lightest sleep phase, when the brain paralyzes the body except for the hands and eyelids to prevent injury.

Beyond these facts, certainties become theories. Some researchers suggest that sleep repairs body tissues, restores muscles, or allows the brain's frontal regionresponsible for speech and creativityto rest. However, these processes might occur equally effectively during relaxed wakefulness, leaving scientists uncertain.

Nevertheless, scientists generally agree that women sleep about thirty minutes longer than men, and that older people require less sleep, though the reasons remain unclear. When asked about sleep's purpose, some researchers offer philosophical answers: "Sleep is a strategy to move through time without harm."

Historical evidence suggests people may have had different sleep patterns in the past. A history professor investigating British nighttime life between 1500 and 1850 discovered that sleep routines differed significantly. People would go to bed around nine or ten o'clock, wake after midnight following their "first sleep," remain awake for about an hour, and then return to sleep for their "morning sleep."

This nighttime interval provided opportunity for reflection, dream recollection, or even theft. The poorest members of society benefited most from this quiet period, briefly escaping the demands and labor that dominated their daytime lives.

By the seventeenth century, as artificial lighting became more widespread, wealthy people began adopting the continuous sleep pattern common today, which proved more economically efficient. Two centuries later, the Industrial Revolution extended working hours in illuminated buildings for most people, further establishing this sleep pattern.

Outside Europe and America, the historical sleep pattern remained common until recently. According to a prominent anthropologist, some non-Western communities still maintain flexible bedtimes. People sleep for a few hours, wake up, and then sleep again. The concept of uninterrupted nighttime sleep doesn't apply. In certain tribal societies, human and animal noises, combined with the need to tend fires and watch for predators, make continuous sleep impossible. It appears that people worldwide are significantly lacking in sleep.
